Yes, hosting the Olympic Games can also have negative effects or consequences, some of which are long-lasting. Here are some examples:

1. Cost - The cost of hosting the Olympic Games can be extremely high, with estimates reaching into the billions of dollars in some cases. This money is often spent on constructing new infrastructure, sports facilities, and other amenities that are only used for the duration of the Olympic Games. The investment may not be sustainable or proportionate to the long-term benefits that the host city will receive.

2. Displacement - The construction of new infrastructure for the Olympic Games can also lead to the displacement of local residents and businesses. People may be forced to move out of their homes or neighborhoods to make way for construction projects, which can have significant social and economic impacts.

3. Environmental impact - The Olympic Games can also have a significant impact on the environment, particularly in terms of energy use, waste generation, and transportation. The construction of sports facilities and transportation infrastructure can lead to the destruction of natural habitats and disruptions to ecosystems.

4. Debt - Some host cities have experienced financial difficulties after hosting the Olympics, with the cost of the event leading to significant debt and budget shortfalls. This can have long-term implications for the city's economy, public services, and infrastructure.

Overall, while the Olympic Games can bring many benefits to host cities, it is important to carefully consider the potential negative effects and consequences before committing to hosting such a large and expensive event.
